subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.
msgSnippet: Joining this conversation quite late, though it is one that I am happy to see proceeding! ... One major problem with this would be that the two kanas are often
messageBody:
Joining this conversation quite late, though it is one that I am happy to see proceeding!

On Wed 2007.05.30, at 04:55, Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
... the difference between Hiragana and Katakana could have been handled as analogous to the Roman/Italic distinction in Latin ...

One major problem with this would be that the two kanas are often used in the same sentence: they encode different meaning (though I suppose the same could occasionally be argued the emphatic distinction between roman/italic).  That might happen in an article which discusses Read's works, but otherwise I think would be quire rare for Quickscript/Shavian.

Although I was originally strongly in favor of separating Quickscript from Shavian, I admit there is a lot of crossover and that the code-points could be reused.  Excite/Examine/Llan/Loch can certainly be additional code points.  I have two questions about the similarities/differences between the two character sets, though:
1) how would Shavian's two separate encodings of the schwa be mapped into Quickscript?  By convention, Quickscript can settle on just one of the characters, but how would the other get 'converted' on the fly when changing fonts?
2) Clearly there is agreement no NOT encode ligatures, but Shavian has four or so hard-coded ligatures: how would these be translated to Quickscript?

oliver

Joining this conversation quite late, though it is one that I am  
happy to see proceeding!

On Wed 2007.05.30, at 04:55, Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
> ... the difference between Hiragana and Katakana could have been  
> handled as analogous to the Roman/Italic distinction in Latin ...

One major problem with this would be that the two kanas are often  
used in the same sentence: they encode different meaning (though I  
suppose the same could occasionally be argued the emphatic  
distinction between roman/italic).  That might happen in an article  
which discusses Read's works, but otherwise I think would be quire  
rare for Quickscript/Shavian.

Although I was originally strongly in favor of separating Quickscript  
from Shavian, I admit there is a lot of crossover and that the code- 
points could be reused.  Excite/Examine/Llan/Loch can certainly be  
additional code points.  I have two questions about the similarities/ 
differences between the two character sets, though:
1) how would Shavian's two separate encodings of the schwa be mapped  
into Quickscript?  By convention, Quickscript can settle on just one  
of the characters, but how would the other get 'converted' on the fly  
when changing fonts?
2) Clearly there is agreement no NOT encode ligatures, but Shavian  
has four or so hard-coded ligatures: how would these be translated to  
Quickscript?

oliver


--Apple-Mail-1-463994359
